title: Extensions can't access sync storage when using a profile on a RAMdisk
content:
Some time ago I moved my Firefox profile to a RAMdisk using IMDisk Virtual Disk Driver on Windows 10. Nearly everything worked fine, apart from certain extensions (e.g. Google Container), which either didn't work at all, or wouldn't allow options to be saved.

The common factor seemed to be that these extensions needed "sync storage" and weren't able to access it when the profile was on the RAMdisk, even though it had worked fine when it was on the C drive. (Note, it made no difference whether I had Firefox Sync configured to sync addon data or not - the relevant thing is that the extensions were using "sync storage" as their way of storing information locally.)

The workaround I eventually found was to move storage.sqlite and storage-sync-v2.sqlite back to my C drive, and create symlinks in my profile folder on the RAMDisk pointing back to them.

This isn't too bad: the size of the data is small and writes are fairly infrequent, and I can certainly live with the workaround.

However, it still seems like a bug, so I'm posting this (1) in case it's useful to anyone else who finds it, (2) to ask whether I should raise it on Bugzilla?

Some questions you might ask:

  • Was this specific profile corrupt?

That wasn't the problem: I could replicate the issue by creating a brand new clean profile on the RAMdisk.

  • Is this a problem with Firefox SQLite databases on the RAMdisk generally?

No: places.sqlite, cookies.sqlite and all the rest of them can be written and read just fine. I wonder if the sync storage code is using different Windows APIs to access files than the rest of Firefox is?

  • Is this a problem with having the profile somewhere other than the C drive, rather than being RAMdisk-specific?

No: you can even put the profile on a USB flash drive and it works fine (well, slowly, but without the problem I described).

  • What if you create a directory junction so that the profile appears to be on the C drive, when it's on the RAMdisk?

That didn't work either - only moving the files physically back to the C drive fixed it.

title: UI to puke on
content:
After an automatic update Firefox had a terrible surprise for me. A beyond ugly user interface. And NO WAY to fix this with a simple toggle switch back to classic mode. There are theme's available, but still it looks unusable to me. This kind of updates should be beyond Mozilla, maybe don't hire former Apple employees, the esthetics don't have to be " slick and modern"

So after a long fight with almost losing my plugins, saved tabs (100+) etc.. I downgraded successfully to 88.

Step 1 (Secure your profile) Open menu, Click Help, Click "More Troubleshooting Information" Go to the line which says, "Profile Folder" Hit open folder

Pay extra attention during these steps: Now you are browsing in your active profile. If you did this after upgrading to 89 version. Make a back-up copy of this whole folder!! Rename it back up.

Open the file "Compatibility.ini" with a text editor, and empty it. Save and close.

Download and install the previous version of Firefox, After installing don't forget to disable automatic updates.

If the profile isn't loaded, browse to "about:profiles" and find and select your profile to get al your plugins, tabs, favs, etc. back.

Its a terrible shame i need to write this down for people to avoid the frustration of a terrible update

title: Logged in device location completely wrong on https://accounts.firefox.com/settings
content:
The Firefox account settings page displays a list of logged in devices at the very bottom of the page (connected services).

I have verified all logged in devices to be correct. However for one of the devices (my main computer browser), the location displayed is COMPLETELY off. I live in Norway, and it claims device location is somewhere in Oregon, United States. I do not use any VPN services and both my public IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are located in Norway, from which I connect with the device/browser in question (whatismyipaddress.com shows correct location for both of them). Also, activity timestamp is updated in accordance with my own activity from the client, but the location remains wrong. I also tried logging out the device, and logging back in, but this did not fix the location.

Obviously the location service used for the logged in device list is unreliable. I suggest that you please also show the latest IP address used by each device, so that more technically inclined users can verify correct addresses themselves, should the location be way off. It is unsettling to see strange locations (for known devices) on a page used to verify the security of my Firefox account. In this instance, there is no security breach, but it required me to spend much time investigating.

I do not know if it matters, but the device in question is a Linux desktop Firefox client.

title: Bookmarks integrity failure
content:
1. macOS Catalina 10.15.7
  2. Firefox 89.0 (compile id: 20210527174632)
  3. Add-ons installed: YT SponsorBlock, BD TraffiLight, uBlock O., YT NonStop

From about 4 months, I had a problem that when I added a bookmark, it was correctly displayed in the bookmarks list but when I clicked on one of them, nothing happend (no redirection). I have added like 30 bookmarks this way, as I didn't have time to debug the reason (and I assumed that description of the bookmark will be enough to find it in the future).

Today I decided to make something about it. I browsed the "places.sqlite" and I found out, that all of the broken bookmarks have "null" value in the "fk" column in the "moz_bookmark" schema.

I did a big mistake, as I run "Verify Integrity" on "places", that cost me all of my bookmarks without "fk". I thought that, it will only "verify" integrity, not try to fix it. But long story short, I lost all of them by doing that.

I did "Manage bookmarks" -> "restore" -> from yesterday. It didn't bring back my bookmarks without "fk" (what a silly name - "backup", if it saves only a subset of data).

Is there any way, I am not familiar with, in which I can bring my "corrupted" (without "fk") bookmarks back ?

title: Cambiamenti del mondo
content: Gentile Firefox, sono un affezionato di Firefox: non uso altri browser, ho sempre lottato contro i ripetuti tentativi dei vari siti o piattaforme di costringere l'utente ad adottare Chrome o altri browser "benedetti". Credo nell'Open. Sono un ricercatore e cerco di divulgare open tutto quello che scrivo. Stamattina vedo il "nuovo" Firefox che mi viene presentato come "più nuovo, più bello, più performante ecc.", ma ciò che io VEDO (perché è ciò che VEDIAMO che conta e non ciò che ci contano) è che le freccette a sinistra avanti-indietro sono più piccole, il pulsante Mostra avanzamento download (che si usa spessissimo) è più piccolo e così pure il pulsante Apri menu applicazione. Quindi, nella sostanza, l'uso di Firefox per me da stamattina è diventato più scomodo. Questa è la novità (come diceva Lucio Dalla). Comprendo ovviamente la necessità di aggiornamenti e miglioramenti "di sistema", ma perché si debbano cambiare continuamente gli aspetti dell'interfaccia non lo capisco. Perché poi questi cambiamenti debbano essere sempre nel senso di usare caratteri SEMPRE PIU' PICCOLI lo capisco ancor meno. Voi direte: sei vecchio. Ma perché uno giovane non si rovina ugualmente la vista? Quanto potete continuare a rimpicciolire caratteri e simboli, finché non diventeranno microscopici: e allora, cosa avrete ottenuto? Notate che la logica del cambiamento NECESSARIO E CONTINUO è una logica consumistica e non di vero progressismo: la ribellione oggi consiste nel ribellarsi a queste logiche e difendere ciò che già è buono senza alcun bisogno di "migliorarlo" (in primis: il Mondo, la Terra, l'Aria, l'Acqua, la Realtà Reale). Chiedo a chi legge di inoltrare, se può, questa mia doglianza a chi può fare qualche cosa per evitare che al prossimo "rinnovamento" di Firefox io debba comprarmi una lente di ingrandimento per guardare lo schermo (e non ditemi che si può ingrandire: non si può passare il tempo ad ingrandire lo schermo). Grazie per l'attenzione e un cordiale saluto Gianni Mignone

title: Firefox Desktop Reading List
content:
Hello all,

I use Firefox on desktop and on phone. The phone version of Firefox offers a reading list so I can temporarily save pages for later reading. Desktop, however, doesn't support this which means that what I have in my reading list on the phone, is not accessible on the desktop.

For desktop, I've downloaded a reading list add-on and saved some pages there. The problem here is that add on is not accessible on mobile which means I can't read any pages on mobile that I've saved on the desktop.

So basically, if I save something on the desktop reading list, it's on desktop only. If I save something on the mobile reading list, it's just there.

I can't save pages on one device and read them on another. I do not understand why Firefox offers a reading list on the mobile app but not on desktop. Whatever the reason, it's inconvenient. Also, I don't want to use Pocket because that means I'd have to download Pocket on the phone, I shouldn't need an app to build a small reading list. Saving the pages to my bookmarks isn't an option because it's inconvenient plus a bookmark is for long-term saving, a reading list is more temporary.

Any ideas on how I can just quickly temporarily save a page for later reading that will be available on both desktop and mobile? Thanks.

title: Newest Firefox ruined the search function...help!
content:
I always used the original Firefox search as my home page; one simple little panel in the middle of the page with a quick and easy search feature. I loved it. The latest version of Firefox has ruined it. Now we are forced to search from the address bar. I hate, loathe, and despise doing a search from the address bar. It is an A-1 nightmare. After you type one letter, it stops registering what you type and throws up a ridiculously long list of the web pages you've visited. Type another letter, and you have to go through this mess again. It makes for an absurdly slow search and never actually gets you to what you're searching for. I wound up with search results that weren't even related to each other much less related to what I was searching for. After one day of use, I'm so frustrated with this feature that I'm opening Google to do the search.

How do we reset this new version of Firefox to only search from the Firefox homepage search box and not go anywhere near that address bar? Or do I have to uninstall the latest update to get Firefox to function properly again? Even if it's an add-on that forces the search to where it belongs...anything!
creator: Waterfaery

title: how to comment on a support discussion
content:
I don't see where/how to comment on the discussion thread "Did the latest Firefox revision change the themes?" I like these comments:

david-donna david-donna Question owner 6/3/21, 2:24 PM

This is a reply to Seburo:

Firefox might have thought that their redesign was inviting, but I find it anything but. The thing that I don't like is that the top header is now very light in color. This means that there is virtually no contrast with the items on top, making reading those items very difficult! In addition, the bookmark list has changed. Space between list of bookmarks has increased, which makes looking for bookmarks much more difficult.

I am all for faster browsers, but let's not get carried away with appearance redesigns that do not help improve one's experience. I would very much appreciate going back to the previous Firefox appearance.

I don't like the new changes. I'm sure there isn't a way to go back, but is there a way to at least make some changes?

title: Firefox 89.0 rapid image changes are distorted
content:
Firefox 89.0 64bit on Devuan (beowulf) Linux 4.19.0-16-amd64x86_64, NVidia GeForce GTX1080 that renders X, video and videogames perfectly well using nvidia module.

Before update to 89.0, no evident rendering problems. From the first page viewed in 89.0, any rapidly changing image on screen starts distorted - blocks of varying widths, maybe 10 points high, change like a distortion or static. I get it on THIS page; if I scroll up and down quickly, fragments of my text show up in broken blocks near the bottom; especially when I scroll from the white background to the dark block underneath.

I get it when trying to NOT-quickly scroll though the Troubleshooting Information Firefox provides when I hit the "Share Data" button. Seems to appear in... the last lower sixth of the screen of a full-screen window. In a smaller window, it'll happen in the lower HALF of the window. Happens on all three monitors of a three-monitor setup.

Most evident when scrolling a page quickly, trying to advance time on an in-page video, on first-load of graphics in page... is there any way to roll back this change, is there an alternate renderer or any other option?

Don't get me wrong, the interface change is awful, detaching the apparent tab-header from the page is weird, the simplified line-based icons in the URL bar are unsettling and the dialog "window" when trying to close multiple tabs in a window looking ever more like Chrome all really SUCK. BADLY. But I could put up with those like every other damned UI change. But the rendering breaking is a deal-breaker. Please, please help if possible.
creator: Troff
